schedule.topic: Course overview and goals, introduction to computing, logistics, software

Computers and Programming Fundamentals: introduction to computer architecture and functioning of a computer, declarative vs. imperative knowledge in programming languages, natural vs. formal languages, compilers vs. interpreters
Basic Python: python objects, scalar vs. non-scalar types, basic operators for numeric types, notion of functions, introduction to Jupyter notebook files, experimenting with basic python concepts

Variables: simple algorithms, assignment operator, variables, high-level vs. machine-level handling of variables and information data, address references and variable identifiers, type casting and conversions, basic ideas on code debugging and style rules
Boolean data types, conditionals : Boolean variables, relational operators, logical operators, flow control using conditional constructs, indentation and scoping
Lab: Use of all primitive data types, operators (numeric, relational, logical) program branching and decision-making using conditionals
schedule.notes: Textbook Chapters 2 and 5 (except sections using Lists)

schedule.topic: String data types 1: Notation, overloaded operators, non-scalar types and indexing, slicing, slicing with a stride
String data types 2: immutability, indexing but not modifying, notion of methods, useful string methods (properties and use), encoding (integer to binary and vice versa)
Lab: Operations on and manipulation of string data types
Lists and Tuples 1: syntax, assignment, indexing and slicing, access information by index and by content, general concepts on data structures (discussion of the homework + lab tests)
Lists and Tuples 2: mutability vs. immutability, more on indexing and slicing, updating lists, operator overloading, concatenation and product
Lab: lists and tuples
schedule.notes: Textbook Chapter 4, first section, and Chapter 7, second section

schedule.topic: Lists and Tuples 3: retrieving, adding, and removing elements using methods, slicing and cloning, aliasing vs. cloning, methods and utility functions available for lists
Lists and Tuples 4: more on list methods, reversing, sorting, min and max, key functions for compariso, list and string methods
Preparation for the midterm exam I, Review of all homework so far
MIDTERM EXAM I (written): All topics considered so far in the course
Iteration 1: Repeated actions using for loops (definite loops), structure and properties of a for construct, examples of typical use, using not using the loop variable, range() generator
Iteration 2: More on for loops, examples of use, while loops (indefinite loops), sentinel variables
Iteration 3: Nested for and while loops, break and continue statements, changinng loops variables, more examples of use, matrix data structure
schedule.notes:
Lecture PDF

Python code used in lecture

schedule.topic: Functions for decomposition, abstraction, and reusability: use of functions, categories of functions, returning values, scope of function variables, control flow when calling a function, modifying input (mutable) parameters, positional and keyword parameters, use of keyword parameters for setting default values, passing an arbitrary number of arguments
More on the use of functions (see slides of previous lecture), practice of functions and lists
Fall Break
Fall Break
Fall Break

Functions 2, Modules: Abstraction and decomposition using functions, specifications and docstrings, inline commetns, use of function arguments, modules to group functions, import statements, dot notation, examples of useful modules

Associative data types, Dictionaries 1: creating labeled data using dictionaries, lists vs. dictionaries, type restrictions, initialization, access, updating, removal of entries, inspection of dictionaries using dynamic view objects, iterating over the items and over the keys
Practice for exam: Practice on topics so far, more on dictionaries
MIDTERM EXAM II (programming): All topics considered so far in the course (little on dictionaries)

schedule.topic: Dictionaries 2: More practice on dictionaries, review of techniques for iterating over the elements of a dictionary, addition and removal of elements, useful methods for sorting and finding max/mix
Dictionaries 3: More practice on dictionaries, initialization and creation of dictionaries, useful operations on dictionary data, review of available methods and functions
Sets 1: Definition of sets, sets vs. lists vs. dictionaries, modalities for creating a set, operations on sets, available methods and functions
Sets 2, Files 1:
Files 2: Text vs. Binary files, examples of the different formats, hierarchy of text data (bits, bytes, fieds, records, file), open methods, opening modes, read method, read text and binary files

Files 3: Methods for reading files using bytes and lines, positioning the read/write head, methods for writing files, examples of use, closing files, handling exceptions with try-except-else-finally construct
Files 4: Practice on files and exceptions, string formatting with str.format() method
